Comment: 'To grow up, be an adult' is tuutɛ.
The latter means 'full of food and/or drink'.
The latter means 'full of food and/or drink'.
Lit. 'it-do-end-our-hand-plural' = 'It's the end of our two hands'. Numbers from five to ten are not usually used. French numbers are borrowed.
Lit. 'pair-four' = 'one pair and four'. Also yanɛ-pɔ-lɔwaya, lit. 'our-hand-other-side'.
Also mɔlɛyɔ̃, in the Kuc dialect.
Also mɛmɔlɛyɔ̃, in the Kuc dialect.
Also pɛsu, in the Camopi dialect.
The latter means 'straight line on the river', lit. 'view-long'.
The latter means 'straight line on the river', lit. 'view-long'.
Lit. 'small-false'. Also -u, in derived nouns. 'Giant' is -wasu.
Respectively: end of a thing; end of a path.
Respectively: end of a thing; end of a path.
To open a pocket knife is -wapɨyawɔ.
Without movement. With movement, is alu-pi, contracted form from alu-lupi.
Without movement. With movement, is ɛnɔnɛ-lupi, lit. 'front-movement'.
Lit. 'soil/ground-toward-to'. 'Down over there' is wɨ̃ĩmɛ; 'down here' is kɛwɛ.
Also means 'measure' 12.540. Also means 'try', because of the hesitating fluctuations of the balance scale.
Lit. 'child-concerning', because the tax is paid every year with the child benefits' money from the government.
Also means 'take' 11.130. 'To pay back' as in revenge is lɛ-pɨ, a very important Tupi-Guaranian ancient war concept.
Also -mɔ-ɛna-ɛ, for destruction of human establishments, lit. 'make-village-end'.
Means 'end of navigation upstream'. Also ɨa-ipɨɨ-ka, lit. 'canoe-keep-where'.
From 'camisa'; means 'cloth', from which the sails are made.
Lit. 'motor-place', used for a dugout with an outboard motor.
Lit. 'fire-place', used because the ships use fire for locomotion.
Respectively: tree trunk used to cross river; 'river-noise' (produced by water passing over tree trunk).
Respectively: tree trunk used to cross river; 'river-noise' (produced by water passing over tree trunk).
Respectively: to bring to; take away.
Respectively: to bring to; take away.
Irregular verb. Respectively: 'I go; he/she goes; we go'.
Irregular verb. Respectively: 'I go; he/she goes; we go'.
Irregular verb. Respectively: 'I go; he/she goes; we go'.
Used only for indigenous black paint, lit. 'make-black'. For modern paint, no generic concept, but 'to whiten' is -mɔ-sĩ; 'to blacken' is -mɔ-piyũ.
Lit. 'money-gold', from Galibi 'karakuli'and from French 'l'or'. Cf. 'money' 11.430.
From French 'la scie'. Also wɨla-wɨla-lɛta-ka, lit. 'wood-wood-cut-which'.
The latter especially used for 'hollow out a canoe'. Also see previous entry.
The latter especially used for 'hollow out a canoe'. Also see previous entry.
Respectively, with a bucket; and with a bottle.
Respectively, with a bucket; and with a bottle.
Respectively: ancient stone ax, lit. 'stone-ax' 01.440; metal ax.
Respectively: ancient stone ax, lit. 'stone-ax' 01.440; metal ax.
From Wayana 'malija' 05.380. Also kɨsɛ, an old Tupi word, almost archaic. Cf. 'cut' 09.220.
A wild liana, Lonchocarpus chrysophyllus. No generic term. Also kunami, Clibadium sylvestre, an herbaceous cultivated plant.
From Port. 'açúcar', through Surinamian Creole 'sukuru', then through Wayana 'asikalu'.
Respectively: Guadua latifolia is the main species, no generic term; another bamboo; 'reed'.
Respectively: Guadua latifolia is the main species, no generic term; another bamboo; 'reed'.
Respectively: Guadua latifolia is the main species, no generic term; another bamboo; 'reed'.
Lagenaria siceraria, from a Carib or Arawak coastal language.
Respectively: tapioca; name of plant: Manihot esculenta. Cassava bread is mɛyu; cassava flour is kwakɨ.
Respectively: tapioca; name of plant: Manihot esculenta. Cassava bread is mɛyu; cassava flour is kwakɨ.
From French '(noix de) coco', through French Creole 'coco'.
Respectively: Euterpe oleracea; Oenocarpus bacaba; Maximiliana maripa. Many species; no generic term.
Respectively: Euterpe oleracea; Oenocarpus bacaba; Maximiliana maripa. Many species; no generic term.
Respectively: Euterpe oleracea; Oenocarpus bacaba; Maximiliana maripa. Many species; no generic term.
Respectively: dead tree stump; live tree stump, lit. 'tree stump-shoot'.
Respectively: dead tree stump; live tree stump, lit. 'tree stump-shoot'.
Second term is indigenous cigar; final term is an imported cigarette, lit. 'white cigar'.
Second term is indigenous cigar; final term is an imported cigarette, lit. 'white cigar'.
Second term is indigenous cigar; final term is an imported cigarette, lit. 'white cigar'.
Also ɨwa- or -ɨ, used in compound words.
Respectively: any herbaceous plant; restricted to a certain species (Polygonum punctatum); graminaceous grasses.
Respectively: any herbaceous plant; restricted to a certain species (Polygonum punctatum); graminaceous grasses.
Respectively: any herbaceous plant; restricted to a certain species (Polygonum punctatum); graminaceous grasses.
Means 'machete', from French 'sabre', through French Guiana Creole.
From Port. 'ferreiro', through old Nheengatu 'pereru' (iron tool), and recent Nheengatu 'purure' (hoe).
Refers to a very small ditch used for agricultual purposes.
Respectively: 'to work in cooperative groups; to hoe weeds'.
Respectively: 'to work in cooperative groups; to hoe weeds'.
Refers to a slash and burn garden.
Respectively: a slash-and-burn field; new field; an old field, fallow.
Respectively: a slash-and-burn field; new field; an old field, fallow.
Respectively: a slash-and-burn field; new field; an old field, fallow.
Wooden trough used to scrape cassava tubers. Deep trough for cassava beer is ɨa-tuluwa, lit. 'canoe-pot'.
Also refers to a 'torchlight', which also has indigenous incense.
From French 'pile'. Also lalã, from French 'la lampe'.
From French 'la table'. Also wɨlapɛ-kalɛta-kusiwa, lit. 'plank-paper-write'.
Means any stool. Someone's stool is -l-ɛna.
Means 'hammock'. Respectively: any hammock; and someone's hammock. A 'bed' is yɛapɨpa, lit.'where someone lies down', used at the field hospital.
Means 'hammock'. Respectively: any hammock; and someone's hammock. A 'bed' is yɛapɨpa, lit.'where someone lies down', used at the field hospital.
Very old Tupi word, common in other Tupi languages.
Refers to the palm (Iriartea exorrhiza), from which the wood of the trunk was formerly used for flooring.
From French 'la clé'. The first term is more integrated in the phonological system; the second is used less by monolingual speakers.
From French 'la clé'. The first term is more integrated in the phonological system; the second is used less by monolingual speakers.
Lit. 'cassava-trough-place'. Also mɔ-sikɔ-awɨ, lit. 'where it's worked under'.
Refers to the central square of village.
Refers to any house. Someone's house is -l-ɛna. Cf. 'beehive' 03.822.
Perhaps from French 'miroir'; or from old Tupi aluwa, 'make oneself beautiful', now archaic.
An indigenous product (Carapa guianensis). Imported ointment is pɔma, from French 'pommade'.
Refers to face painting, means 'on the face'. 'Body painting' is yɔwaka.
Refers both to indigenous seed beads and to imported glass beads.
For the wrist, lit. 'wrist-hole'. An ankle bracelet is tapakula.
Respectively: 'loin-cloth' for a man; from French 'pantalon'.
Respectively: 'loin-cloth' for a man; from French 'pantalon'.
From Port. 'camisa' (shirt). Also tɨpɔy, woven cotton, for baby carrying belt.
Refers to rain cape, lit. 'rain-prevent'. 'War cloak' is apɛla.
From Span. 'coser (sew)' or 'aguja' (needle), through a coastal language, perhaps Arawak-Locono 'akosa'; or Galibi 'akusa'; and then, through Wayana 'kakusa'.
Refers to animal skin, hide, cf. 04.120.
For a man, lit. 'one-self-masc. loin-cloth-put'. For a woman is -y-[kamisa]nũ, from Port. 'camisa'; lit. 'one-self-fem. loin-cloth-put'.
Respectively: generic term—several kinds of fermented drinks, mostly made from cassava. From Arawak-Locono, through Wayana, 'to drink manioc beer collectively'.
Respectively: generic term—several kinds of fermented drinks, mostly made from cassava. From Arawak-Locono, through Wayana, 'to drink manioc beer collectively'.
Means mother's milk, lit. 'breast-liquid'. From an imported can is [tilɛ], from French 'du lait'.
Respectively: from English 'salt', through Surinamian Creole 'sautu' and then through Wayana 'hautu'; archaic term for ancient salt made of palm ashes.
Respectively: from English 'salt', through Surinamian Creole 'sautu' and then through Wayana 'hautu'; archaic term for ancient salt made of palm ashes.
Respectively: indigenous; from French 'huile'; 'crabwood oil' (Carapa guianensis).
Respectively: indigenous; from French 'huile'; 'crabwood oil' (Carapa guianensis).
Respectively: indigenous; from French 'huile'; 'crabwood oil' (Carapa guianensis).
Indigenous species (Phaseolus lunatus). Imported species is [salikɔ] (Phaseolus vulgaris), from French 'haricot'.
Made from cassava starch. Any vegetable soup is papa.
The latter is used as a classifier. 'Smoked meat' is kãʔɛ̃.
The latter is used as a classifier. 'Smoked meat' is kãʔɛ̃.
Refers to sugar cane press, lit. 'sugar cane-wring' 08.941.
From French 'farine', made from wheat. Flour from maize is kuʔi; from fresh cassava is pɨlatɨ; from roasted cassava meal is [kwakɨ], from French Creole of French Guiana 'couac'.
Refers to fresh cassava dough when scraped.
Indigenous cassava bread. Also imported flour bread, [pɔlɔtɔ], from Dutch 'brood', through Palikur 'burut'.
Respectively: an old Tupi word, almost archaic; from Wayana 'malija'.
Respectively: an old Tupi word, almost archaic; from Wayana 'malija'.
Respectively: from Wayana 'makuwa'; 'jar for manioc beer'.
Respectively: from Wayana 'makuwa'; 'jar for manioc beer'.
Indigenous clay pot. A metal pot is [patu], from Wayana 'patu'.
Means 'that is round'. 'Kiln' is tata-lɛna, lit. 'fire-place'.
Respectively: trans.; intrans. The latter means 'have a meal'.
Respectively: trans.; intrans. The latter means 'have a meal'.
From French 'docteur', refers to M.D., medical doctor. 'Shaman' is payɛ, 22.430.
Refers to a bump or hump. A blue mark is sɔ̃wɨ̃-ma, lit. 'blue-completely'.
For a man speaking. A woman speaking is -y-mɛnɔ̃.
Lit. 'sleep-snore'; form not used in contemporary Wayápi, but occurs in other Tupi languages.
Archaic Tupi, used only for animals.
Also, archaic Tupi kama, not used now, but occurs in compounds. Cf. 'udder' 04.420.
The latter also means 'trachea'. 'Adam's Apple' is sẽʔẽ.
The latter also means 'trachea'. 'Adam's Apple' is sẽʔẽ.
Also ãɨ̃ and ãy, in compound forms.
For mammals. Also means 'antenna of insect'. Horn of insect is sĩtɨʔãy.
Respectively: 'land t.' (Geochelene denticulata); 'water t.' Phrynops nasutus; Podocnemis unifilis.
Respectively: 'land t.' (Geochelene denticulata); 'water t.' Phrynops nasutus; Podocnemis unifilis.
Respectively: 'land t.' (Geochelene denticulata); 'water t.' Phrynops nasutus; Podocnemis unifilis.
Lit. 'honey-father'. ɛila is old or archaic Tupi form for 'honey', ɛi.
Refers to American puma (Felis concolor), lit. 'jaguar red' 15.660.
Respectively: Symbranchus marmoratus; 'electric eel' Electrophorus electricus.
Respectively: Symbranchus marmoratus; 'electric eel' Electrophorus electricus.
Means 'mussel', the only shell in Wayãpi territory.
'Great horned owl' (Bubo virginianus). Also used as generic.
From a Carib language, refers to indigenous species. Also [kana], refers to imported species; from French 'canard'.
Lit. 'peccary-white'. 'White-lipped p.(Tayassu pecari)' is tayau. 'Collared p. (Tayassu tajacu)' is taitɛtu.
Respectively: verbal prefix; pronoun form. Also aʔe 'him/her'.
Respectively: verbal prefix; pronoun form. Also aʔe 'him/her'.
Of a man, referential form. Address form is pisĩ. Referential form, of a woman is mɛmɨ-l-aʔu. Address form is pisĩ.
Lit. 'man's son-a little'. Of a man, referential form. Address form is piʔa. Referential form, of a woman, is mɛmɨ-l-aʔu. Address form is pisĩ.
Lit. 'mother-a little'. Referential form. Address form is mãmã.
Lit. 'father-a little'. Referential form. Address form is papa.
Referential form. Address form is mãsĩ.
Referential form. Address form is mãsĩ. Also pisĩ. Also means 'niece' 02.540, because a girl marries her cross-cousin.
Lit. 'man's daughter-husband'. Referential form. Address form is kwani. Also means 'nephew', because a boy marries his cross-cousin.
Referential form. Address form is pipi. Also means 'aunt' 02.520.
Referential form. Also yayɛ-aʔu. Address form is pipi. Also pipi-aʔu. Also means 'aunt' 02.520.
Referential form. Also -l-atɨ-aʔu. Address form of a woman is paʔi. Also tɨtɨ. Also means 'uncle' 02.510.
Referential form. Also -l-atɨ-aʔu. Address form of a man is paʔi. Also tɨtɨ. Also means 'uncle' 02.510.

Lit. 'man's son-?'. Of a man, referential form, referring to all sisters' daughters. Address forms, mãsĩ; pisĩ. For a woman, referring to 'niece' (her brothers' daughters), referential form is mɛmɨ-tatɨ. Address forms are mãsĩ; pisĩ.

Lit. 'man's daughter-husband'. Of a man, referential form, referring to all sisters' sons. Address form is kwani. For a woman, referring to nephew (i.e. her brothers' sons), referential form is pɛ̃; address form is suwi.
Referential form, for father's sisters and the classificatory fathers' sisters. Address form is pipi.
Respectively: referential form; address form. Also mean 'mother' 02.360.
Respectively: referential form; address form. Also mean 'mother' 02.360.
Respectively: referential form; address form. Also mean 'father' 02.350.
Respectively: referential form; address form. Also mean 'father' 02.350.
Referential form. Address form is paʔi.
Referential form, only for mother's brothers and classificatory mothers' brothers. Address form is paʔi.
Referential form, from a Carib language. Address form is yaʔɨ. Also piʔa; tuku; ɛ-palɨ.
Referential form, from a Carib language. Address form is pisĩ. Also ɛ-palɨ.
Referential form. Address form is saʔi.
Referential form. Address form is tãmũ.
This word is used for classificatory siblings also, i.e. sons and daughters of father's brothers, and sons and daughters of mother's sisters.
Lit. 'older sister-little'. Of a man, referential form. Address form is pisĩ. Referential form, of a woman is kɨpɨʔɨ. Address form is pisĩ.
Of a man, referential form. Address form is yãyã. Referential form, of a woman is -l-ɨkɛ. Address form is yãyã. In other Tupi-Guaranian languages, this term means 'woman'.
Of a man, referential form. Address form is tuku. Also piʔa. Referential form, of a woman is kɨwɨ. Address form is tuku. Also piʔa.
Of a man, referential form. Address form is kakãy. Referential form, of a woman is kɨwɨ. Address form is kakãy.

Of a man, referential form. Also used for brothers' daughters. Also yaʔɨ. Address form is pisĩ. Referential form, of a woman is mɛmɨ, which is also used for all sisters' daughters. Address form is pisĩ. Also yaʔɨ.

Of a man, respectively: referential form; address form. Also tuku; piʔa. Also used for all brothers' sons. Referential form, of a woman is mɛmɨ. Address forms are tuku; piʔa. Also used for all sisters' sons.

Of a man, respectively: referential form; address form. Also tuku; piʔa. Also used for all brothers' sons. Referential form, of a woman is mɛmɨ. Address forms are tuku; piʔa. Also used for all sisters' sons.
Respectively: referential form; and address form. The two forms are also used for all mother's sisters.
Respectively: referential form; and address form. The two forms are also used for all mother's sisters.
Respectively: referential form; and address form. The two forms are also used for all father's brothers.
Respectively: referential form; and address form. The two forms are also used for all father's brothers.
Used for true wife and classificatory wives.
Used for true husband and classificatory husbands.
In other Tupi-Guaranian languages, this term means 'old woman'.
Used for males in certain circumstances such as sex, hunting, war. For farmers the collective plural yɔkɛ is used.
The latter in Brazilian dialect, from Nheengatu 'mira (man)'.
The latter in Brazilian dialect, from Nheengatu 'mira (man)'.
From French 'allumette', in the French Guiana dialect. Brazilian dialect has [palitɔ], from Port. 'palito'.
Respectively: the usual sense of 'burn'; refers to slash-and-burn cultivation.
Respectively: the usual sense of 'burn'; refers to slash-and-burn cultivation.
Refers to artificial ice. Means 'what is cold'.
Also ɛãŋɛ, which refers only to humans.
The two latter forms are used as classifiers, such as in pinaʔɨ 'fishing rod'; and ɨwapɛ 'tree flat'.
The two latter forms are used as classifiers, such as in pinaʔɨ 'fishing rod'; and ɨwapɛ 'tree flat'.
The two latter forms are used as classifiers, such as in pinaʔɨ 'fishing rod'; and ɨwapɛ 'tree flat'.
Means 'sand-large' 01.215. Can mean sea or river. 'Shore' of river is ɨ-lɛmɛ, lit. 'river-lip' 04.250.
Lit. 'our-on-good' = '[sun is] in good position above us'.
Also means 'string calendar', used to remember festival chronology.
Also means 'sun'; refers to dry season; see 14.760.
Refers to wet season; also means 'rain' 01.750.
Refers to dry season; also means 'year' 14.730.

'Wet season' is divided into three: amãalɨpɨ, Dec. to March; kwataka, April to May; wasɛyiwa, June to July. 'Dry season' is divided into three: kwalaɨpɨ, Aug. to Sept.; kwalaɨmɨɨtɛ, Oct.; alɛmɨ, Nov.
The latter example means 'to look for, locate game'.
The latter example means 'to look for, locate game'.
The latter is used in compound nouns.
The latter is used in compound nouns.
The final two forms are verbal.
The final two forms are verbal.
The final two forms are verbal.

Respectively, three classes of human spirits are listed: soul of a living person; 'vital breath' put into the newborn; spirit which cannot leave the earth at death, is represented by the shadow of the living person 01.630.

Respectively, three classes of human spirits are listed: soul of a living person; 'vital breath' put into the newborn; spirit which cannot leave the earth at death, is represented by the shadow of the living person 01.630.

Respectively, three classes of human spirits are listed: soul of a living person; 'vital breath' put into the newborn; spirit which cannot leave the earth at death, is represented by the shadow of the living person 01.630.
Means 'punish', lit. 'make-think'. Also -mɔ-mɔlĩyau 'be punished at school'; cf. 'famine' 05.141.
Also -kuwa ã laʔi ɛsa, 'see to know a little, reflect'.
Respectively: indigenous concept; modern 'school-master'. Suffix -ya means 'master of any kind of knowledge'.
Respectively: indigenous concept; modern 'school-master'. Suffix -ya means 'master of any kind of knowledge'.
Respectively: habit, custom; suffix, meaning 'used for'.
Respectively: habit, custom; suffix, meaning 'used for'.
Without movement in the action: e.g. mapɛ ɛlɛikɔ, 'where are you?' With movement is mapɛ-kɨtɨ, e.g. mapɛkɨtɨ ɛlɛɔ, 'where are you going?'
In the Brazilian dialect, means 'person, human being'.
Also ɛɛwa, the true name, inherited from an ancestor's name.
Means 'choose the secret name of a child'. During adult life, it is prohibited to name someone.
The latter is, lit. 'do too much'.
The latter is, lit. 'do too much'.
Also amaʔɨwu and tulɛ, like a clarinet.
Also amaʔɨwu and tulɛ, like a clarinet.
Cf. English 'maraca'. Used for shaman's instrument, an important concept in Indian culture. 'Shake the rattle' is -mɔkasa.
Means the person living in the village, or each member of the tribe. Cf.19.210.
Respectively: referential form; archaic word. Also atɨwa. Address form is yɛpɛ. Cf. 'pair' 13.370.
Respectively: referential form; archaic word. Also atɨwa. Address form is yɛpɛ. Cf. 'pair' 13.370.
Invited to drink; -ʔu is 'drink'. Invited to eat is yɛmiʔukwayta.
For drinking; lit. 'cassava beer-master'. For eating is yɛmiʔuã.
Means traditional warrior. White soldier is [sɔta], from French 'soldat'.
From Wayana 'kapalu'. Also wɨlasĩ, old Tupi word.
From Wayana 'palakta', a tree (Manilkara sp), from which an elastic gum is extracted.
Refers to any bow; someone's bow is -l-apama.
The reed from which arrows are made (Gynerium sagittatum) is wɨwa.
Also [alakausa], from Port. or Span. 'arcabuz', through Galibi 'arakapusa', then Wayana 'alakapua'. Both terms are only used in a nonpersonal context (see 'bow' 20.240). Someone's gun is -l-apa.
Lit. 'dog-theft', because of a special ceremony, with a ritual theft.
Also [ukɨ], archaic, from English 'hook', through Surinamian Creole 'uku', then through Wayana ukə.
From African Bantu 'maswa', through Maroon Ndjuka 'maswa' and Maroon Aluku 'masuwa', and finally through Galibi 'masiwa'.
No native word for 'hunt'; the meaning is expressed, e.g., in 'see, watch, kill, be at war, to bring back'. E.g., a-a a-wɛla, 'I go/ I bring back' = 'I go to hunt'.
The latter from Creole 'la geole', Old French word for 'prison'.
The latter from Creole 'la geole', Old French word for 'prison'.
From French 'mon père', used only for Catholic priests.
Refers to indigenous concept for magic affairs and magic practices.
Refers to indigenous shaman or pajé.
No generic term. Numerous creatures are recognized: those of the forest (first term above), 'cannibal spirits'; those of the river (second term above), 'river's inhabitants'.
No generic term. Numerous creatures are recognized: those of the forest (first term above), 'cannibal spirits'; those of the river (second term above), 'river's inhabitants'.
